galvanize.meaning: verb: to excite or inspire (someone) to action
galvanize.sentence: At mile 23 of his first marathon, Kyle had all but given up, until he noticed his friends and family holding a banner that read, “Go Kyle”; galvanized, he broke into a gallop, finishing the last three miles in less than 20 minutes.

equivocal.sentence: The findings of the study were equivocal—the two researchers had different opinions on what the results signified.

harangue.meaning: noun: a long pompous speech; a tirade
harangue.sentence: Dinner at Billy's was more a punishment than a reward, since anyone who sat at the dinner table would have to listen to Billy's father's interminable harangues against the government.

impertinent.meaning: adjective: being disrespectful; improperly forward or bold
impertinent.sentence: Dexter, distraught over losing his pet dachshund, Madeline, found the police officer’s questions impertinent—after all, he thought, did she have to pry into such details as to what Madeline’s favorite snack was?

egregious.meaning: adjective: standing out in a negative way; shockingly bad
egregious.sentence: The dictator’s abuse of human rights was so egregious that many world leaders demanded that he be tried in an international court for genocide.

venality.meaning: noun: the condition of being susceptible to bribes or corruption
venality.sentence: Even some of the most sacred sporting events are not immune to venality, as many of the officials have received substantial bribes to make biased calls.

parsimonious.sentence: Katie is so parsimonious that she only buys a pair of socks if all of her other socks have holes in them.

commensurate.meaning: adjective: to be in proportion or corresponding in degree or amount
commensurate.sentence: The convicted felon’s life sentence was commensurate with the heinousness of his crime.

parochial.meaning: adjective: narrowly restricted in scope or outlook
parochial.sentence: Jasmine was sad to admit it, but her fledgling relationship with Jacob did not work out because his culinary tastes were simply too parochial; "After all," she quipped on her blog, "he considered Chef Boyardee ethnic food."

upbraid.sentence: Bob took a risk walking into the "Students Barbershop"—in the end he had to upbraid the apparently drunk barber for giving him an uneven bowl cut.

involved.meaning: adjective: complicated, and difficult to comprehend
involved.sentence: The physics lecture became so involved that the undergraduate’s eyes glazed over.

frugal.meaning: adjective: not spending much money (but spending wisely)
frugal.sentence: Monte was no miser, but was simply frugal, wisely spending the little that he earned.

castigate.sentence: Drill sergeants are known to castigate new recruits so mercilessly that the latter often break down during their first week in training.

demur.meaning: verb: to object or show reluctance
demur.sentence: Wallace disliked the cold, so he demurred when his friends suggested they go skiing in the Alps.

ingenuous.meaning: adjective: to be naïve and innocent
ingenuous.sentence: Two-years in Manhattan had changed Jenna from an ingenuous girl from the suburbs to a jaded urbanite, unlikely to fall for any ruse, regardless of how elaborate.

prevaricate.meaning: verb: to speak in an evasive way
prevaricate.sentence: The cynic quipped, “There is not much variance in politicians; they all seem to prevaricate”.

vindicate.meaning: verb: to clear of accusation, blame, suspicion, or doubt with supporting arguments or proof
vindicate.sentence: Even seven Tour de France wins cannot vindicate Lance Armstrong in the eyes of the public--that the athlete used performance enhancing drugs invalidates all those wins.

amenable.sentence: Even though she did not like the outdoors, Shirley was generally amenable and so her brother was able to persuade her to go camping.

ambivalent.meaning: adjective: mixed or conflicting emotions about something
ambivalent.sentence: Sam was ambivalent about studying for the exam because doing so ate up a lot of his time, yet he was able to improve his analytical skills.

venerate.sentence: The professor, despite his sleep-inducing lectures, was venerated amongst his colleagues, publishing more papers yearly than all of his peers combined.

intimate.sentence: At first Manfred’s teachers intimated to his parents that he was not suited to skip a grade; when his parents protested, teachers explicitly told them that, notwithstanding the boy’s precocity, he was simply too immature to jump to the 6th grade.

artful.sentence: Picasso is generally considered the most artful member of the Cubist movement.

mercurial.meaning: adjective: (of a person) prone to unexpected and unpredictable changes in mood
mercurial.sentence: The fact that Ella’s moods were as mercurial as the weather was problematic for her relationships—it didn’t help that she lived in Chicago.

disinterested.sentence: The potential juror knew the defendant, and therefore could not serve on the jury, which must consist only of disinterested members.

calumny.meaning: noun: making of a false statement meant to injure a person’s reputation
calumny.sentence: With the presidential primaries well under way, the air is thick with calumny, and the mud already waist-high.

acrimony.sentence: The acrimony between the president and vice-president sent a clear signal to voters: the health of the current administration was imperiled.

Magoosh.meaning: noun: An online GRE prep product used by tens of thousands of students worldwide. Learn more at gre.magoosh.com.
Magoosh.sentence: After using Magoosh, Tom improved his GRE score by 8 points and was then admitted into UC Berkeley.

undermine.meaning: verb: to weaken (usually paired with an abstract term)
undermine.sentence: The student undermined the teacher’s authority by questioning the teacher’s judgment on numerous occasions.

iconoclast.meaning: noun: somebody who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions
iconoclast.sentence: Lady Gaga, in challenging what it means to be clothed, is an iconoclast for wearing a "meat dress" to a prominent awards show.

wanting.sentence: She did not think her vocabulary was wanting, yet there were so many words that inevitably she found a few she didn't know.

laconic.meaning: adjective: (describes a person, speech, or style of writing) using very few words
laconic.sentence: While Martha always swooned over the hunky, laconic types in romantic comedies, her boyfriends inevitably were very talkative—and not very hunky.

amorphous.sentence: His study plan for the GRE was at best amorphous; he would do questions from random pages in any one of seven test prep books.

innocuous.meaning: adjective: harmless and doesn’t produce any ill effects
innocuous.sentence: Everyone found Nancy’s banter innocuous—except for Mike, who felt like she was intentionally picking on him.

enervate.sentence: John preferred to avoid equatorial countries; the intense sun would always leave him enervated after he’d spent the day sightseeing.

extant.meaning: adjective: still in existence (usually refers to documents).
extant.sentence: Despite many bookstores closing, experts predict that some form of book dealing will still be extant generations from now.

qualify.meaning: verb: to make less severe; to limit (a statement)
qualify.sentence: Chris qualified his love for San Francisco, adding he didn't like the weather there as much as he liked the weather in Los Angeles.

restive.sentence: The crowd grew restive as the comedian’s opening jokes fell flat.

betray.meaning: verb: to reveal or make known something, usually unintentionally
betray.sentence: With the gold medal at stake, the gymnast awaited his turn, his quivering lip betraying his intense emotions.

anomalous.sentence: According to those who do not believe in climate change, the extreme weather over the last five years is simply anomalous—daily temperatures should return to their old averages, they believe.

censure.sentence: After being caught in bed with a mistress, the mayor was quickly censured by the city council.

profligate.meaning: adjective: spending resources recklessly or wastefully
profligate.sentence: The composer Wagner, while living on a limited salary, was so profligate as to line all the walls of his apartment with pure silk.

chastise.sentence: Though chastised for eating the snacks for the party, Lawrence shrugged off his mother’s harsh words, and continued to plow through jars of cookies and boxes of donuts.

veracious.sentence: While we elect our leaders in the hope that every word they speak  will be veracious, history has shown that such a hope is naive.

aberration.meaning: noun: a deviation from what is normal or expected
aberration.sentence: Aberrations in climate have become the norm: rarely a week goes by without some meteorological phenomenon making headlines.

apathetic.meaning: adjective: marked by a lack of interest
apathetic.sentence: Mr. Thompson was so talented at teaching math that even normally apathetic students took interest.

audacious.meaning: adjective: willing to be bold in social situations or to take risks
audacious.sentence: As all of the other campers cowered in their tents, Bill, armed only with a flashlight, audaciously tracked down the bear that had raided their food.

impudent.sentence: In an impudent move, the defendant spoke out of order to say terribly insulting things to the judge.

perfidy.meaning: noun: an act of deliberate betrayal; a breach of a trust
perfidy.sentence: Sure, he was the best salesman in the company; but Michael had abused the trust of the firm, sharing product secrets with a competitor, and for such perfidy he was terminated.

recondite.meaning: adjective: difficult to penetrate; incomprehensible to one of ordinary understanding or knowledge
recondite.sentence: I found Ulysses recondite and never finished the book, waiting instead to read it with someone else so we could penetrate its meaning together.

predilection.sentence: Monte had a predilection for the fine things in life: Cuban cigars, 200 dollar bottles of wine, and trips to the French Riviera.

platitude.meaning: noun: a trite or obvious remark
platitude.sentence: The professor argued that many statements regarded as wise in previous times, such as the Golden Rule, are now regarded as mere platitudes.

entrenched.sentence: By the time we reach 60-years old, most of our habits are so entrenched that it is difficult for us to change.

prescience.meaning: noun: the power to foresee the future
prescience.sentence: Baxter's warnings about investing in technology stocks seemed like an act of prescience after the whole market declined significantly.

frivolous.meaning: adjective: not serious in content or attitude or behavior
frivolous.sentence: Compared to Juliet's passionate concern for human rights, Jake's non-stop concern about football seems somewhat frivolous.

diffident.meaning: adjective: showing modest reserve; lacking self-confidence
diffident.sentence: As a young girl she was diffident and reserved, but now as an adult, she is confident and assertive.

gossamer.meaning: adjective: characterized by unusual lightness and delicacy
gossamer.sentence: The gossamer wings of a butterfly, which allow it to fly, are also a curse, so delicate that they are often damaged.

gainsay.meaning: verb: deny or contradict; speak against or oppose
gainsay.sentence: I can't gainsay a single piece of evidence James has presented, but I still don't trust his conclusion.

decorous.meaning: adjective: characterized by good taste in manners and conduct
decorous.sentence: Sally's parties are decorous affairs, and instead of the usual beer and music, there is tea and intellectual conversation.

inexorable.meaning: adjective: impossible to stop or prevent
inexorable.sentence: The rise of the computer was an inexorable shift in technology and culture.

bucolic.meaning: adjective: relating to the pleasant aspects of the country
bucolic.sentence: The noble families of England once owned vast expanses of beautiful, bucolic land.

incisive.meaning: adjective: having or demonstrating ability to recognize or draw fine distinctions
incisive.sentence: The lawyer had an incisive mind, able in a flash to dissect a hopelessly tangled issue and isolate the essential laws at play.

exacerbate.sentence: Her sleeplessness exacerbated her cold--when she woke up the next day, her sinuses were completely blocked.

gall.meaning: noun: the trait of being rude and impertinent
gall.sentence: The speeding car had the gall to switch five lanes at once, run through a red light, and then cut off a police car before finally coming to a stop in front of a sea of flashing red lights.

didactic.sentence: Tolstoy's The Death of Ivan Ilyich is a didactic novel, instructing the reader on how to live a good life.

culpability.sentence: Since John had left his banana peel at the top of the stairwell, he accepted culpability for Martha's broken leg.

aesthete.meaning: noun: one who professes great sensitivity to the beauty of art and nature
aesthete.sentence: A true aesthete, Marty would spend hours at the Guggenheim Museum, staring at the same Picasso.

torpor.meaning: noun: inactivity resulting from lethargy and lack of vigor or energy
torpor.sentence: After work, I was expecting my colleagues to be enthusiastic about the outing, but I found them in a state of complete torpor.

mitigate.meaning: verb: make less severe or harsh
mitigate.sentence: I can only spend so much time mitigating your disagreements with your wife, and at certain point, you need to do it on your own.

banal.meaning: adjective: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse
banal.sentence: The professor used such banal expression that many students in the class either fell asleep from boredom or stayed awake to complete his sentences and humor friends.

volubility.meaning: noun: the quality of talking or writing easily and continuously
volubility.sentence: The professor's volubility knows no bounds; he could talk through a hurricane and elaborate a point from one St. Patrick's Day to the next.

aesthetic.meaning: adjective: concerned with the appreciation of beauty
aesthetic.sentence: The director, not known for his aesthetic sensibilities, decided not to use costumes at all, and put on the play in everyday clothing.

fortuitous.meaning: adjective: occurring by happy chance; having no cause or apparent cause
fortuitous.sentence: Missing my train turned out to be quite fortuitous since I ran into a childhood friend on the next train and we were able to reconnect after so many years.

reticent.meaning: adjective: disinclined to talk, not revealing one's thoughts
reticent.sentence: When asked about her father, Helen lost her outward enthusiasm and became rather reticent.

vociferous.meaning: adjective: conspicuously and offensively loud; given to vehement outcry
vociferous.sentence: In giving Marcia a particular vociferous response, Paul caused people at every other table in the restaurant to turn around and look at them angrily.

preclude.meaning: verb: keep from happening or arising; make impossible
preclude.sentence: The manager specified that all other gates be locked, to preclude the possibility of persons without tickets entering the arena undetected.

engender.sentence: The restrictions of the Treaty of Versailles were so severe that they engendered deep hatred and resentment in the German people.

germane.sentence: The professor wanted to tell the jury in detail about his new book, but the lawyer said it wasn't germane to the charges in the cases.

cryptic.meaning: adjective: mysterious or vague, usually intentionally
cryptic.sentence: Since Sarah did not want her husband to guess the Christmas present she had bought him, she only answered cryptically when he would ask her questions about it.

dogmatic.meaning: adjective: highly opinionated, not accepting that one's own beliefs may not be correct
dogmatic.sentence: Bryan is dogmatic in his belief that the earth is flat, claiming that all pictures of a spherical earth are computer generated.

deferential.sentence: If you ever have the chance to meet the president, stand up straight and be deferential.

culminate.meaning: verb: reach the highest or most decisive point
culminate.sentence: Beethoven's musical genius culminated in the 9th Symphony, which many consider his greatest work.

querulous.sentence: The querulous old woman was beginning to wear down even the happier members of the staff with her ceaseless complaining.

obscure.sentence: On the Smith's drive through the Grand Canyon, Mr. Smith's big head obscured much of Mrs. Robinson's view, so that she only saw momentary patches of red rock.

glut.sentence: The Internet offers such a glut of news related stories that many find it difficult to know which story to read first.

lambast.sentence: Showing no patience, the manager utterly lambasted the sales team that lost the big account.

eschew.meaning: verb: avoid and stay away from deliberately; stay clear of
eschew.sentence: Politicians are the masters of eschewing morals; academics are the masters of eschewing clarity.

mawkish.meaning: adjective: overly sentimental to the point that it is disgusting
mawkish.sentence: The film was incredibly mawkish, introducing highly likeable characters only to have them succumb to a devastating illness by the end of the movie.

rustic.meaning: adjective: characteristic of rural life; awkwardly simple and provincial
rustic.sentence: The vacation cabin had no electricity and no indoor plumbing, but despite these inconveniences, Nigel adored its rustic charm.

chortle.meaning: verb: to chuckle, laugh merrily, often in a breathy, muffled way
chortle.sentence: Walking into the cafe, I could hear happy, chortling people and smell the rich aroma of roasted coffee beans.

meanings.sentence: How can we hope to stay open if we don't eliminate all superfluous spending, like catered meetings and free acupuncture Tuesday?

meanings.meaning: adjective: more than is needed, desired, or required
meanings.sentence: The third paragraph in your essay is superfluous and can be deleted.

lionize.meaning: verb: assign great social importance to
lionize.sentence: Students in the U.S. learn to lionize Jefferson, Franklin, and Washington because they are the founding fathers of the nation.

poignant.sentence: After the Montagues and Capulets discover the dead bodies of Romeo and Juliet,  in the play's most poignant moment, the two griefstricken families agree to end their feud once and for all.

inveterate.sentence: He is an inveterate smoker and has told his family and friends that there is no way he will ever quit.

vacillate.meaning: verb: be undecided about something; waver between conflicting positions or courses of action
vacillate.sentence: Some students vacillate between schools when deciding which to attend, while others focus only on one school.

garrulous.sentence: Lynne was garrulous: once, she had a fifteen minute conversation with a stranger before she realized the woman didn't speak English.

trite.meaning: adjective: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse
trite.sentence: Many style guides recommend not using idioms in writing because these trite expressions are uninteresting and show a lack of imagination on the part of the writer.

prodigious.meaning: adjective: so great in size or force or extent as to elicit awe
prodigious.sentence: After the relatively small homerun totals in the "dead ball" era, Babe Ruth's homerun totals were truly prodigious: every year, he set a new all-time record.

sporadic.meaning: adjective: recurring in scattered and irregular or unpredictable instances
sporadic.sentence: The signals were at first sporadic, but now we detect a clear, consistent pattern of electromagnetic radiation emanating from deep space.

austere.sentence: His lifestyle of revelry and luxurious excess could hardly be called austere.

audacity.meaning: noun: aggressive boldness in social situations
audacity.sentence: Mike was upset at the man who not only cut in front of him at the ticket counter but also had the audacity to cut in front of him at the bathroom line.

pedestrian.sentence: While Nan was always engaged in philosophical speculation, her brother was occupied with far more pedestrian concerns: how to earn a salary and run a household.

intrepid.sentence: Captain Ahab was an intrepid captain whose reckless and fearless style ultimately lead to his downfall.

pernicious.meaning: adjective: exceedingly harmful; working or spreading in a hidden and injurious way
pernicious.sentence: The most successful viruses are pernicious: an infected person may feel perfectly healthy for several months while incubating and spreading the virus.

antithetical.meaning: adjective: sharply contrasted in character or purpose
antithetical.sentence: His deep emotional involvement with these ideas is, in fact, antithetical to the detachment Buddhism preaches.

subversive.meaning: adjective: in opposition to an established system or institution.
subversive.sentence: The ruling political party has begun a campaign to shut down subversive websites that it deems as a threat to "national safety."

reverent.meaning: adjective: feeling or showing profound respect or veneration
reverent.sentence: The professor could speak objectively about the other composers, but he always lectured about Brahms with a particularly reverent air, unable to offer a single criticism of his compositions.

brazen.meaning: adjective: unrestrained by convention or propriety
brazen.sentence: Their large "donations" to the local police department gave the drug cartel the brazen confidence to do their business out in the open.

dilettante.meaning: noun: an amateur who engages in an activity without serious intentions and who pretends to have knowledge
dilettante.sentence: Fred has no formal medical training; while he likes to claim authority on medical issues, he is little more than a dilettante.

munificent.sentence: Uncle Charley was known for his munificence, giving all seven of his nephews lavish Christmas presents each year.

ostracize.meaning: verb: exclude from a community or group
ostracize.sentence: Later in his life, Leo Tolstoy was ostracized from the Russian Orthodox Church for his writings that contradicted church doctrine.

scrupulous.meaning: adjective: characterized by extreme care and great effort
scrupulous.sentence: Because of his scrupulous nature, Mary put him in charge of numbering and cataloging the entire collection of rare stamps.

inscrutable.sentence: His speech was so dense and confusing that many in the audience found it inscrutable.

circumscribe.sentence: Their tour of South America was circumscribed so that they saw only popular destinations and avoided the dangerous parts of cities.

propitious.meaning: adjective: presenting favorable circumstances; likely to result in or show signs of success
propitious.sentence: The child's heartbeat is still weak, but I am seeing many propitious signs and I think that she may be healing.

foment.meaning: verb: try to stir up public opinion
foment.sentence: After having his pay cut, Phil spread vicious rumors about his boss, hoping to foment a general feeling of discontent.

accolade.meaning: noun: an award or praise granted as a special honor
accolade.sentence: Jean Paul-Sartre was not a fan of accolades, and as such, he refused to accept the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1964.

constituent.meaning: noun: a citizen who is represented in a government by officials for whom he or she votes
constituent.sentence: The mayor's constituents are no longer happy with her performance and plan to vote for another candidate in the upcoming election.

prolific.sentence: Schubert was the most prolific composer, producing hundreds of hours of music before he died at the age of 31.

sanction.meaning: verb: give authority or permission to
sanction.sentence: The authorities have sanctioned the use of the wilderness reserve for public use; many expect to see hikers and campers enjoying the park in the coming months.

arcane.meaning: adjective: requiring secret or mysterious knowledge
arcane.sentence: Most college fraternities are known for arcane rituals that those hoping to join the fraternity must learn.

myriad.sentence: There are a myriad of internet sites hawking pills that claim to boost energy for hours on end.

haphazard.meaning: adjective: marked by great carelessness; dependent upon or characterized by chance
haphazard.sentence: Many golf courses are designed with great care, but the greens on the county golf course seem entirely haphazard.

irrevocable.meaning: adjective: incapable of being retracted or revoked
irrevocable.sentence: Once you enter your plea to the court, it is irrevocable so think carefully about what you will say.

rescind.sentence: The man's driver's license was rescinded after his tenth car accident, which meant he would never be allowed to legally drive again.

repudiate.meaning: verb: reject as untrue or unfounded
repudiate.sentence: Many in the public believed the rumors of a UFO crash outside town, so the chief of police did everything he could to repudiate the rumors.

gauche.sentence: Sylvester says the most gauche things, such as telling a girl he liked that she was much prettier when she wore makeup.

sycophant.meaning: noun: a person who tries to please someone in order to gain a personal advantage
sycophant.sentence: The CEO was unaware of the damaging consequences of his choices, largely because he surrounded himself with sycophants who would never dare criticize him.

tempered.sentence: The wide-eyed optimism of her youth was now tempered after she had worked many years in the criminal justice system.

resurgent.meaning: adjective: rising again as to new life and vigor
resurgent.sentence: The team sank to fourth place in June, but is now resurgent and about to win the division.

winsome.meaning: adjective: charming in a childlike or naive way
winsome.sentence: She was winsome by nature, and many people were drawn to this free and playful spirit.

tractable.meaning: adjective: readily reacting to suggestions and influences; easily managed (controlled or taught or molded)
tractable.sentence: Compared to middle school students, who have an untamed wildness about them, high school students are somewhat more tractable.

arbitrary.meaning: adjective: based on a random, groundless decision
arbitrary.sentence: One of the arbitrary decrees in place during the emperor's rule is that all citizens pay him weekly homage at his palace.

taciturn.sentence: While the CEO enthusiastically shares his plans and agenda with all who will listen, the CFO is far more taciturn, rarely revealing his perspective.

nonplussed.meaning: adjective: unsure how to act or respond
nonplussed.sentence: Shirley was totally nonplussed when the angry motorist cut her off and then stuck his finger out the window.

capricious.meaning: adjective: determined by chance or impulse or whim rather than by necessity or reason
capricious.sentence: Nearly every month our capricious CEO had a new plan to turn the company around, and none of them worked because we never gave them the time they needed to succeed.

maladroit.sentence: As a child she was quite maladroit, but as an adult, she has become an adept dancer.

mendacity.meaning: noun: the tendency to be untruthful
mendacity.sentence: I can forgive her for her mendacity but only because she is a child and is seeing what she can get away with.

transient.meaning: adjective: lasting a very short time
transient.sentence: The unpredictable and transient nature of deja vu makes it a very difficult phenomenon to study properly.

edifying.meaning: adjective: enlightening or uplifting so as to encourage intellectual or moral improvement
edifying.sentence: I recently read an article in the Times about whether good literature is edifying or not; specifically, does reading more make a person more moral.

craven.sentence: Though the man could have at least alerted the police, he crouched cravenly in the corner as the old woman was mugged.

erudite.meaning: adjective: having or showing profound knowledge
erudite.sentence: Before the Internet, the library was typically where you would find erudite readers.

specious.meaning: adjective: based on pretense; deceptively pleasing
specious.sentence: Almost every image on TV is specious and not to be trusted.

arduous.meaning: adjective: demanding considerable mental effort and skill; testing powers of endurance
arduous.sentence: In order to deal with the arduous cross-country journey, truck drivers often survive on a string of caffeinated drinks, staying awake for up to 30 hours at a time.

imprudent.sentence: Hitler, like Napoleon, made the imprudent move of invading Russia in winter, suffering even more casualties than Napoleon had.

jovial.meaning: adjective: full of or showing high-spirited merriment
jovial.sentence: The presidential candidate and her supporters were jovial once it was clear that she had won.

ignominious.meaning: adjective: (used of conduct or character) deserving or bringing disgrace or shame
ignominious.sentence: Since the politician preached ethics and morality, his texting of revealing photographs was ignominious, bringing shame on both himself and his party.

maverick.meaning: noun: someone who exhibits great independence in thought and action
maverick.sentence: Officer Kelly was a maverick, rarely following police protocols or adopting the conventions for speech common among his fellow officers.

opulence.meaning: noun: wealth as evidenced by sumptuous living
opulence.sentence: Russian oligarchs are famous for their opulence, living in fancy homes and dining on expensive caviar.

timorous.meaning: adjective: timid by nature or revealing fear and nervousness
timorous.sentence: Since this was her first time debating on stage and before an audience, Di's voice was timorous and quiet for the first 10 minutes.

anomaly.meaning: noun: something that is not normal, standard, or expected
anomaly.sentence: After finding an anomaly in the data, she knew that she would have to conduct her experiment again.

polemic.meaning: noun: a strong verbal or written attack on someone or something.
polemic.sentence: The professor launched into a polemic, claiming that Freudian theory was a pack of lies that absolutely destroyed European literary theory.

reproach.sentence: At first, Sarah was going to yell at the boy, but she didn't want to reproach him for telling the truth about the situation.

sullen.meaning: adjective: showing a brooding ill humor
sullen.sentence: Herbert took board games too seriously, often appearing sullen after losing.

furtive.meaning: adjective: marked by quiet and caution and secrecy; taking pains to avoid being observed
furtive.sentence: While at work, George and his boss Regina felt the need to be as furtive as possible about their romantic relationship.

rebuke.meaning: verb: criticize severely or angrily; censure
rebuke.sentence: The police chief rebuked the two officers whose irresponsible decisions almost led to the deaths of seven innocent by-standers.

dilatory.sentence: Lawyers use dilatory tactics so that it takes years before the case is actually decided.

stringent.meaning: adjective: demanding strict attention to rules and procedures
stringent.sentence: Most of the students disliked the teacher because of his stringent homework policy, but many students would later thank him for demanding so much from them.

askance.meaning: adverb: with a look of suspicion or disapproval
askance.sentence: The old couple looked askance on the teenagers seated next to them, whispering to each other, "They've got rings through their noses and purple hair!"

elicit.meaning: verb: call forth (emotions, feelings, and responses)
elicit.sentence: Just smiling--even if you are depressed--can elicit feelings of pleasure and happiness.

efficacious.sentence: Since Maggie's cough syrup, which had expired five years back, was no longer efficacious, she coughed through the night.

bolster.sentence: The case for the suspect's innocence was bolstered considerably by the fact that neither fingerprints nor DNA were found at the scene.

mundane.meaning: adjective: repetitive and boring; not spiritual
mundane.sentence: Nancy found doing dishes a thorougly mundane task, although Peter found a kind of Zen pleasure in the chore.

appease.meaning: verb: pacify by acceding to the demands of
appease.sentence: Neville Chamberlain, the British prime minister during WWII, tried to appease Hitler and in doing so sent a clear message: you can walk all over us.

harried.meaning: adjective: troubled persistently especially with petty annoyances
harried.sentence: With a team of new hires to train, Martha was constantly harried with little questions and could not focus on her projects.

disseminate.meaning: verb: cause to become widely known
disseminate.sentence: Before the effects of anesthesia were disseminated, patients had to experience the full pain of a surgery.

Magoosh Score Estimator.meaning: noun: After taking a practice exam, determine your score on the GRE 340-point scale.  Learn more at http://gre.magoosh.com
Magoosh Score Estimator.sentence: Mike scored a 335 on a practice exam using the Magoosh score estimator.

duress.sentence: The witness said he signed the contract under duress and argued that the court should cancel the agreement.

flux.meaning: noun: a state of uncertainty about what should be done (usually following some important event)
flux.sentence: Ever since Elvira resigned as the head of marketing, everything about our sales strategy has been in a state of flux.

contrition.meaning: noun: the feeling of remorse or guilt that comes from doing something bad
contrition.sentence: Those who show contrition during their prison terms--especially when under review by a parole board--often get shortened sentences.

misconstrue.meaning: verb: interpret in the wrong way
misconstrue.sentence: The politician never trusted journalists because he thought that they would misconstrue his words and misrepresent his positions.

posit.sentence: Initially, Einstein posited a repulsive force to balance Gravity, but then rejected that idea as a blunder.

economical.sentence: Journalists favor an economical style of writing, in which no unnecessary words are used and every sentence is as short as possible.

banality.meaning: noun: a trite or obvious remark
banality.sentence: Herbert regarded the minister's remark as a mere banality until Sharon pointed out profound implications to the seemingly obvious words.

indecorous.meaning: adjective: not in keeping with accepted standards of what is right or proper in polite society
indecorous.sentence: Eating with elbows on the table is considered indecorous in refined circles.

nuance.meaning: noun: a subtle difference in meaning or opinion or attitude
nuance.sentence: Because of the nuances involved in this case, I hired an outside consultant to advise us and help.

antipathy.meaning: noun: an intense feeling of dislike or aversion
antipathy.sentence: Maria had an antipathy for tour groups, often bolting to the other side of the museum as soon as she saw a chaperone leading a group of wide-eyed tourists.

placate.meaning: verb: cause to be more favorably inclined; gain the good will of
placate.sentence: I was able to placate the angry mob of students by promising to bring cookies on Monday.

deleterious.sentence: The BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico was deleterious to the fishing industry in the southern states.

fastidious.meaning: adjective: overly concerned with details; fussy
fastidious.sentence: Whitney is fastidious about her shoes, arranging them on a shelf in a specific order, each pair evenly spaced.

esoteric.meaning: adjective: confined to and understandable by only an enlightened inner circle
esoteric.sentence: Map collecting is an esoteric hobby to most, but to geography geeks it is a highly enjoyable pastime.

dispassionate.meaning: adjective: unaffected by strong emotion or prejudice
dispassionate.sentence: A good scientist should be dispassionate, focusing purely on what the evidence says, without personal attachment.

impartial.meaning: adjective: free from undue bias or preconceived opinions
impartial.sentence: The judge was not impartial since he had been bribed by the witness's family.

pejorative.meaning: adjective: expressing disapproval (usu. refers to a term)
pejorative.sentence: Most psychologists object to the pejorative term "shrink", believing that they expand the human mind, not limit it.

truncate.meaning: verb: reduce the length of something
truncate.sentence: The soccer game was truncated when the monsoon rain began to fall.
